body:
>This is however not the case with Alacritty, none of my alacritty sessions (nor tmux sessions that I create within an Alacritty session) are shown in who. Is there a reason for alacritty somehow flying under the system's radar?

if you read what `who` does with `man who`. it's showing information about users logged in. Logging in multiple times doesn't sound right to me. The thing you see in alacritty is true for most linux terminal btw and for tmux.
FWIW, I tried this on El Capitan, and both Terminal.app and Alacritty show both console and tty lines. I'm not sure what changed with Catalina.

@krlvi, each terminal session would potentially be it's own TTY session (more info here: http://www.linusakesson.net/programming/tty/).

It could be that I've just done something locally that messes this up. I'll try running alacritty on a colleague's computer tomorrow!
you can type `tty` to get corresponding session, but there's nothing to do with login.

Usually we should spawn a login shell, that's certainly not wrong.

If you change your shell to `login -fp $USER` for example, I think that should resolve this issue.

However there's a big problem with the `login` command, it doesn't allow changing the working directory:

https://github.com/gnachman/iTerm2/blob/f6b54d66b5e371b9e69a0881e9608e13e710fda1/sources/shell_launcher.c#L1-L5

There are several hacks to work around this and it seems like Alacritty just picks one which doesn't do everything you want.
More info can be found in the old login shell issue: https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/issues/1071

@HendrikPetertje do you have a custom shell entry in your config, or are you just using the default? If my understanding of this issue is correct, our default should work as expected for you.

Perhaps we have an issue with custom shells on macOS?

> If my understanding of this issue is correct, our default should work as expected for you.

It shouldn't.

@chrisduerr care to elaborate?

The linked issue (and PR) changed the default shell to a bash wrapper that launches a login shell, which is what I understand to be the solution to this issue. Or does the macOS hack need to also run `login`?

Turns out I can replicate this on El Capitan, it's just not consistently an issue.

EDIT: after rereading #1856, it's unclear to me how that solution ever worked, since it doesn't run `login`, and instead relies on `bash`.

I've tested:

```rust
Shell::new_with_args("/usr/bin/login", vec!["-fp".into(), "<username>".into()])
```

and it seemed to fix this issue. Maybe the original hack needs some work? Sorry if I'm missing something, I don't recall the original hacks context.

Yes, the thing is that we cannot use the `login` shell since it doesn't allow setting the working directory.

That's why I've mentioned previously that you can just set `login -fp $USER` as your shell in the configuration file if you don't care about that and it'll work just fine.

The linked iTerm code does things slightly differently, but in an even more hacky way than Alacritty. One would have to test iTerm first to see if we could adapt that to work in Alacritty though. But even then, the Rust STD API does not allow for this hackery since it's in no way how things are intended to work, so one would likely have to rely on some lower level unsafe platform APIs and the output of `who` just doesn't matter enough to me to look into that.

If anyone is interested in trying to fix this, a PR would obviously be very welcome and the original PR should basically tell you everything you need to know. But I don't see myself fixing this anytime soon.

Thanks for all thereplies everyone, I just logged in after my long weekend and noticed all the comments here. 

I’m totally fine with Alacritty not showing up as a TTY if that is expected behavior. if you want to change that as per discussed, then that’s fine by me, but not a life-threatening thing in any way ofc.

To answer the question of start command, yes I have set zsh on mine, so that might have affected things too.

Feel free to close this issue if you want. If others want to continue the discussion, that’s fine too

I found this issue while troubleshooting something related.  It seems on Catalina you need to start a shell with `login` or something that already has (eg. Terminal.app).

Not using `login` breaks anything that uses `logname` to detect the current user. 

with no Alacritty config file, starting Alacritty from Spotlight
```
$ who
deekue console  Jun 16 07:49
$ logname
root
$ tty
/dev/ttys003
```
with no Alacritty config file, starting from Terminal.app
```
$ who
deekue console  Jun 16 07:49
deekue ttys004  Jun 18 21:12
$ tty
/dev/ttys004
$ logname
deekue
```

I get different results if I start alacritty from `login` (with no config file)
`login -pf $USER /usr/local/bin/alacritty --config-file /dev/null`
```
$ tty
/dev/ttys004
$ who
deekue console  Jun 16 07:49
deekue ttys003    Jun 18 21:13
$ logname
deekue
```
versus specifying `login` as the shell in the alacritty config,
`alacritty --config-file <(echo "shell: {program: '/usr/bin/login', args: [ '-pf', 'deekue']}"`
```
$ logname
deekue
$ who
deekue console  Jun 16 07:49
deekue ttys004  Jun 18 21:13
$ tty
/dev/ttys004
```

This seems to be affecting other apps/terminals too
- https://github.com/laravel/valet/issues/904
- https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/96463
- https://github.com/vercel/hyper/issues/3762

though not iTerm2 since it [appears to use login](https://github.com/gnachman/iTerm2/blob/3624330bb2ae1a6aa41842b9b4e71ffb4f59945a/sources/shell_launcher.c)

issue.title: Register shells launched by Alacritty as tty sessions on macOS
issue.body:
Unless the `shell` config is specified, launch the user's shell with:

```sh
login -flp $USER /bin/sh -c "exec -a -shell /path/to/shell"
```

On macOS, just running a shell prefixed by `-` is not sufficient to be
registered as a login session for things like `w` and `logname`.
However, using the `login` command changes the directory to `$HOME`
before running the program by default, which is not desired. The `-l`
flag disables this behavior, but also skips prepending `-` to the
executed program, so shells will not run as login shells. Instead we
just do this part ourselves with `exec -a`. The result is login shells
that run in the intended directory and are registered as tty sessions.

Update `alacritty.yml` to reflect that Alacritty will use `$SHELL` or
the user's login shell on Linux, BSD, and macOS.

Fixes #3420
